item.title: A Programmer's Guide to Public Speaking
item.description:
Description

Every developer can be a great public speaker. Learn actionable public speaking tips distilled from more than a decade of stand-up, improv, and sketch comedy. After this talk, you'll feel more confident delivering daily standups, company meetings, and conference talks.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/a-programmers-guide-to-public-speaking

Sun Aug 4 11:50:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Donna Zhou

item.title: Changing what’s normal: how to transfer concepts between groups
item.description:
Description

This talk focuses on how to change people’s minds, and successfully introduce new concepts to groups and individuals without damaging relationships.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/changing-whats-normal-how-to-transfer-concepts-between-groups

Sun Aug 4 10:30:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Maia Sauren

item.title: Conference Close
item.description:
Description

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/990c-close/

Sun Aug 4 17:00:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Unknown

item.title: Devpi for teams
item.description:
Description

Building python packages in a team can be a complicated process. Devpi can assist in reducing this complexity by hosting your own content and making it seamlessly available with the rest of the packages on pypi. It also provides resiliency, robustness and auditability to your teams build process.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/devpi-for-teams

Sun Aug 4 11:10:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Graham Williamson

item.title: Environment Variables: how software impacts climate change
item.description:
Description

How can we minimise our software’s contribution to climate change? How do we make software that can withstand climate change-related disasters? How do we deal with the knowledge that we’re careening towards catastrophe?

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/environment-variables

Sun Aug 4 14:50:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Merrin Macleod

item.title: Extending MicroPython: Using C for good!
item.description:
Description

MicroPython is a fantastic environment for embedded development. But it is an interpreted language; what happens when you hit performance limitations? Or want to use a new feature of your microcontroller? We’ll look at how MicroPython can be extended to add features and improve performance.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/extending-micropython-using-c-for-good

Sun Aug 4 13:30:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Matt Trentini

item.title: Git hook[ed]” on images & up your documentation game
item.description:
Description

Can you remember the difference between two hex color values? Me neither! Entering visual representations of recent-changes into version control makes review of past changes easier & speeds acclimation to a new web project. Join me for a review of current methods & how to choose the best for you!

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/git-hooked-on-images-up-your-documentation-game

Sun Aug 4 14:10:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Veronica Hanus

item.title: Insights into Social Media Data using Entropy Theory
item.description:
Description

Entropy theory is usually thought of as something that applies to matter and energy, but it turns out that we can apply the same techniques of analysis to social media sites. Join me as we study the thermodynamic behaviour of users on Twitter, and learn how to analyse it better.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/insights-into-social-media-data-using-entropy-theory

Sun Aug 4 11:10:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Mars Geldard

item.title: Instant-feedback, instant-debugging Python coding
item.description:
Description

Building on Bret Victor's famous 'Inventing on Principle' presentation, we look at writing Python where the code is instantly run and every line visualized after every single keystroke. There's a future beyond the text-editor → console-run loop and this is a taste of it.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/instant-feedback-instant-debugging-python-coding

Sun Aug 4 14:10:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Robert Lechte

item.title: It's dark and my lights aren't working (an asyncio success story)
item.description:
Description

I have invested huge amounts of time in achieving a simple goal -- making the lighting in my home "smart". It's not ground breaking, nor is it practical or cost effective, but it sure was educational, uses a bunch of Python, and the result makes me (and my family) happy.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/its-dark-and-my-lights-arent-working-an-asyncio-success-story

Sun Aug 4 11:50:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Jim Mussared

item.title: Let's Build a Symbolic Analyser And Automatically Find Bugs
item.description:
Description

Learn the theory and practice of symbolic analysis, a method of fake-running your code that lets you discover bugs and verify functionality without actually executing code, using Z3 and Python!

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/lets-build-a-symbolic-analyser-and-automatically-find-bugs

Sun Aug 4 11:50:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Jon Manning

item.title: Micropython Gotchas
item.description:
Description

We all somehow get the feeling that MicroPython is not quite the Python we know. During the talk, I’ll show what the “not quite” actually means. I'll present a set of different issues I stumbled upon when working with different MicroPython powered boards ranging from memory constraints to API calls.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/micropython-gotchas

Sun Aug 4 14:50:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Michał Gałka

item.title: No time to idle about: Profiling import time in Python
item.description:
Description

Python 3.7 added the ability to print import times at startup. But what can we do with that data, and is it enough? In this talk we'll look at how to process import time data, structure it, visualise it, and make concrete choices to improve start up time. Python need not be slow to start!

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/no-time-to-idle-about-profiling-import-time-in-python

Sun Aug 4 14:10:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Daniel Porteous

item.title: Orchestrating complex (not complicated) tasks using AWS serverless and Python
item.description:
Description

Python and serverless technologies are a great way to quickly scale a project, but what can you do when things get complicated? Here are some patterns to keep you sane.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/orchestrating-complex-not-complicated-tasks-using-aws-serverless-and-python

Sun Aug 4 14:50:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Michael Kelly

item.title: Python Oddities Explained
item.description:
Description

Sometimes you’ll find what might seem like a bug in Python but occasionally these bugs reveal themselves to be misunderstood features. During this talk we’ll look at a number of Python’s unique features and quirks and attempt to re-shape our mental models of how Python works.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/python-oddities-explained

Sun Aug 4 13:30:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Trey Hunner

item.title: Shipping your first Python package and automating future publishing
item.description:
Description

One of the best things about Python is the vast ecosystem of packages available on the Python Package Index. Shipping your first Python package can be intimidating. This talk aims to remove the mystery of Python packaging and enable you to share your code with the Python community.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/shipping-your-first-python-package-and-automating-future-publishing

Sun Aug 4 10:30:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Chris Wilcox

item.title: Sunday Lightning Talks
item.description:
Description

Lightning talks are 5 minute talks. You have 5 minutes. 5 shall be the number, and the number shall be 5. 6 is too much.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/sunday-lightning-talks

Sun Aug 4 16:00:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Unknown

item.title: Teaching Python with tiny, occult pandas
item.description:
Description

Microcontrollers, web development, data science and machine learning – with Python you really can do it all, and soon every teacher and student in the ACT will have the curriculum, resources and support they need to do amazing things with a great programming language!

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/teaching-python-with-tiny-occult-pandas

Sun Aug 4 13:30:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Bruce Fuda

item.title: The New COBOL
item.description:
Description

COBOL was one of the first business-oriented programming languages, showing up in the 1960s. It’s also regarded as one of the worst languages in which to work. But is that true? And if so, what could ever take its place as the most reviled thing in dev?

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/the-new-cobol

Sun Aug 4 10:30:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Benno Rice

item.title: The real costs of Open Source Sustainability
item.description:
Description

What if money isn't the only way to create sustainable free and open source software projects? What if it turns out that sustainability is actually a multi-faceted concept that can't truly be successful if people focus on only one of its many elements?

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/vicky

Sun Aug 4 09:20:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: VM Brasseur

item.title: The universe as balls and springs: molecular dynamics in Python
item.description:
Description

Surprisingly, we can approximate matter as a bunch of balls on springs and learn things about our bodies and the world. This talk will look at the different stages of molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and how Python is changing everything.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/the-universe-as-balls-and-springs-molecular-dynamics-in-python

Sun Aug 4 13:30:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Lily Wang

item.title: Volumetric Performance Capture and Playback: A Workflow with Python
item.description:
Description

Volumetric capture is a technique used to film in three dimensions for viewing in a virtual space.This talk will explore the different elements of a full volumetric capture stack, from coordinating usb cameras to playback in a 3D game engine and how python can be used to glue it all together.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/volumetric-performance-capture-and-playback-a-workflow-with-python

Sun Aug 4 14:50:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Luke Miller

item.title: What not to do, and how to do it
item.description:
Description

Python has powerful tools that let our programs inspect and modify themselves. These can be used for good or evil. We study a few of these tools, and some examples of how not to use them.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/what-not-to-do-and-how-to-do-it

Sun Aug 4 11:50:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Jakub Nabaglo

item.title: What PHP learned from Python
item.description:
Description

In 2015, the PHP project released version 7.0 of the PHP language. An advantage PHP had was that Python had gone through a similar process with Python 3 seven years earlier. I'll discuss the lessons taken from the Python 2-3 transition, and how they were applied.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/what-php-learned-from-python

Sun Aug 4 11:10:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Adam Harvey

item.title: Building an interactive training environment using JupyterHub
item.description:
Description

JupyterHub is used to run and manage Jupyter notebook instances for multiple users at the same time. Did you know though that you can use JupyterHub to spawn applications other than Jupyter notebooks? Come see how JupyterHub was used to create a multi user interactive training environment.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/building-an-interactive-training-environment-using-jupyterhub

Sat Aug 3 11:50:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Graham Dumpleton

item.title: Anatomy of a Browser
item.description:
Description

Web browsers are a bit like digestive systems - we all have one, but we're not really sure how it works, and sometimes it makes funny smells. So let's have a look at what's going on under the hood when your browser turns a bunch of characters into a delightful picture of a cat.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/anatomy-of-a-browser

Sat Aug 3 13:30:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Erin Zimmer

item.title: Building a Sustainable Python Package Index
item.description:
Description

Most of us have installed a Python package, but do we know what it takes to make that work in a consistent, reliable way?

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/building-a-sustainable-python-package-index

Sat Aug 3 10:30:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Dustin Ingram

item.title: Creating Lasting Change
item.description:
Description

The Nature of Organisations, People, and how to Change Them

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/aurynn

Sat Aug 3 09:20:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Aurynn Shaw

item.title: Fantastic Blocks And Where To Hide Them
item.description:
Description

Ruby has blocks. JavaScript has blocks. Swift has blocks. Python doesn’t have blocks.In this talk, we'll look at why Python doesn't have blocks, and recent programming techniques that have developed in languages that do have blocks. Then we'll look at what we – or Python – can do about it!

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/fantastic-blocks-and-where-to-hide-them

Sat Aug 3 14:10:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Christopher Neugebauer

item.title: Goodbye Print Statements, Hello Debugger!
item.description:
Description

Still debugging your code with print statements? Learn how to level up your ability to troubleshoot complex code situations by using the power of a fully-featured debugger in this talk aimed at all levels of programming ability.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/goodbye-print-statements-hello-debugger

Sat Aug 3 11:10:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Nina Zakharenko

item.title: How I migrated a huge OSS project to use pytest
item.description:
Description

Over a couple of months in 2018 I developed a script for refactoring GDAL's ancient and arcane test suite to use Pytest. The final pull request was over 118,000 lines. This talk covers how I did it and what I learned.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/how-i-migrated-a-huge-oss-project-to-use-pytest

Sat Aug 3 14:50:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Craig de Stigter

item.title: It's Pythons All The Way Down: Python Types & Metaclasses Made Simple
item.description:
Description

Don't be afraid of metaclasses! This talk will explain how, once you've grasped basic types, classes and inheritance, Python's advanced language features such as descriptors and metaclasses are just within your reach.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/its-pythons-all-the-way-down-python-types-metaclasses-made-simple

Sat Aug 3 10:30:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Mark Smith

item.title: Lessons learned building Python microservices
item.description:
Description

I will talk about challenges and wins that have come from introducing Python into a multilingual microservices kubernetes architecture with lots of legacy.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/lessons-learned-building-python-microservices

Sat Aug 3 10:30:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Richard Jones

item.title: Logging Rethought 2: The Actions of Frank Taylor Jr.
item.description:
Description

We build services, potentially used by thousands or even millions of people. And despite all the testing we do, some interactions with these services will not work out the way we hope. Wouldn’t it be great to reconstruct what let to a problem and analyze if the problem occurred at other times?

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/logging-rethought-2-the-actions-of-frank-taylor-jr

Sat Aug 3 13:30:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Markus Holtermann

item.title: Making Acquaintances with Exotic Encodings
item.description:
Description

Text encoding is a relatively straightforward feature of Python at first glance, but in the wild there are a lot of strange cases we can encounter. Together we will explore some occurences of out-of-ordinary encodings and how to handle them properly in Python.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/making-acquaintances-with-exotic-encodings

Sat Aug 3 11:10:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Trapsilo Bumi

item.title: Post-mortems: Building better software together.
item.description:
Description

Improving the reliability of complex software requires more than just reacting to the latest issue. In this talk we’ll learn how you and your team can work together to build a post-mortem process that helps you identify and fix systematic flaws in your environment.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/post-mortems-building-better-software-together

Sat Aug 3 11:50:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Thomi Richards

item.title: Pretty vector graphics - Playing with SVG in Python
item.description:
Description

Let's make some art! Scalable vector graphics are essentially just big strings of text... and Python is great for manipulating text. Learn how you can get started using text (and a bit of math) to generate art in this fundamentals talk exploring the basics of SVG formatting and manipulation.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/pretty-vector-graphics--playing-with-svg-in-python

Sat Aug 3 11:50:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Amanda J Hogan

item.title: Profiling Pathogens with (micro) Python
item.description:
Description

We're building professional medical diagnostics equipment with micropython. This has come with minimal challenges, many positives and a few surprises!

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/profiling-athogens-with-micro-python

Sat Aug 3 14:50:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Andrew Leech

item.title: Python Applications in Infrastructure Planning and Civil Engineering
item.description:
Description

Engineers tasked with planning new infrastructure constantly face the problem of having to look through too much information. This talk is about how we wanted to be lazy and wrote a bot to do it for us instead.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/python-applications-in-infrastructure-planning-and-civil-engineering

Sat Aug 3 13:30:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Ben Chu

item.title: Saturday Lightning Talks
item.description:
Description

Lightning talks are 5 minute talks. You have 5 minutes. 5 shall be the number, and the number shall be 5. 6 is too much.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/saturday-lightning-talks

Sat Aug 3 16:40:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Unknown

item.title: Sufficiently Advanced Testing
item.description:
Description

Writing tests is great, and generating randomized tests even better... but we can push the techniques further still! What is a metamorphic relation good for? How could (should?) you use a SAT solver for tests? What about symbolic execution, guided fuzzing, delta debugging? Come and find out!

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/sufficiently-advanced-testing

Sat Aug 3 13:30:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Zac Hatfield-Dodds

item.title: The Antipodes
item.description:
Description

Brandon will be speaking at PyCon AU about the antipodes

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/brandon

Sat Aug 3 16:00:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Brandon Rhodes

item.title: Tracing, Profiling & Debugging in Production (eBPF)
item.description:
Description

Trace, Profile & Debug applications in production without restarting or loading a framework.We will look at a number of modern techniques including eBPF and ptrace to attach to running production applications with no preparation and minimal performance impact.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/tracing-profiling-debugging-in-production-ebpf

Sat Aug 3 14:50:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Trent Lloyd

item.title: Tunnel Snakes Rule! Bringing the many worlds of Python together to monitor Melbourne's biggest infra
item.description:
Description

Python is being used to provide real-time environmental monitoring on the Melbourne Metro Tunnel project. Come along to see how open source Python tools from the web, IoT, cloud infrastructure and scientific domains are being used together to monitor environmental telemetry on a city-wide scale.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/tunnel-snakes-rule-bringing-the-many-worlds-of-python-together-to-monitor-melbournes-biggest-infrastructure-project

Sat Aug 3 11:10:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Evan Brumley

item.title: Using comedy as an excuse to play with python-programmed microcontrollers
item.description:
Description

Early-career comedians often have difficulties adding electronic props to their acts, due to the high cost of materials and fabrication skills required. This talk will recreate several props used in comedic performances, showing the code and components used.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/using-comedy-as-an-excuse-to-play-with-python-programmed-microcontrollers

Sat Aug 3 11:50:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Anthony I. Joseph

item.title: When software and law are the same thing
item.description:
Description

In Aotearoa New Zealand the government ran an experiment to encode law openly as python, publish versioned in git, licenced as open source, and available on a hosted as an API.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/when-software-and-law-are-the-same-thing

Sat Aug 3 14:50:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Brenda Wallace

item.title: You might not need gender!
item.description:
Description

This talk will dive into the world of gender and the abounding misconceptions. We have a duty to build systems that allow people to truly represent themselves, and to do this requires an understanding of how to properly store and handle that information.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/you-might-not-need-gender

Sat Aug 3 14:10:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Opal Symes

item.title: 3D Rendering with Python
item.description:
Description

Create 3D rendered animations in a few lines of Python, for teaching concepts in Physics and Astronomy. Let your students write some simple code to, for example, model the movement of a bouncing ball due to gravity, and with only a couple of lines of extra code, actually render and animate the ball.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/3d-rendering-with-python

Fri Aug 2 14:50:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Andrew Williams

item.title: Automagically marking Python course work and assessments in seconds!
item.description:
Description

The author's Python course is being delivered by two academic providers in New Zealand and uses CodeRunner for marking all lab work and assessments. Students receive feedback and marks on the code they write within seconds. Installing CodeRunner, creating labs and code/live demos will be covered.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/automagically-marking-python-course-work-and-assessments-in-seconds

Fri Aug 2 11:10:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Dave Bracken

item.title: Best Practices for Cryptography In Python
item.description:
Description

Part of what makes Python great also brings challenges for cryptographic operations that need rigorous control of memory and CPU instructions. In this talk we'll discuss situations where Python is a poor fit as well as ones where it shines and learn how to work around some of the issues.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/best-practices-for-cryptography-in-python

Fri Aug 2 14:10:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Paul Kehrer

item.title: Building, designing, teaching and training simulation environments for Machine Learning
item.description:
Description

Imagine you're building a fancy robot-driven warehouse. Your pick, place, and packing robots need to get around quickly, find the right item and put it to the right place without colliding with each other, shelves, or people. But you don't have any robots yet, and you need to start. Try simulations!

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/building-designing-teaching-and-training-simulation-environments-for-machine-learning

Fri Aug 2 11:50:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Paris Buttfield-Addison

item.title: Concept to Classroom: Creating fun differentiated programming projects
item.description:
Description

Less is more when it comes to kids coding projects! We'll explore a tried and tested method for creating Minimum Viable Projects, used around Australia to teach kids to code. See how we create fun, challenging, differentiated projects for all abilities with this 5 step process & concept calculator.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/concept-to-classroom-creating-fun-differentiated-programming-projects

Fri Aug 2 13:30:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Renee Noble

item.title: cuDF: RAPIDS GPU-Accelerated Dataframe Library
item.description:
Description

RAPIDS open-source software enables end-to-end data science and analytics pipelines to run entirely on GPUs. Key to RAPIDS is cuDF, a pandas-like Python data frame library with a high-performance CUDA C++ implementation. cuDF and RAPIDS enable large speedups for end-to-end data science using GPUs.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/cudf-rapids-gpu-accelerated-dataframe-library

Fri Aug 2 14:10:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Mark Harris

item.title: Data Sharing in Modern Australia
item.description:
Description

Australia is reshaping data privacy and security aggressively on multiple fronts.How can you manage data security and privacy in your projects while the sands shift around you?

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/data-sharing-in-modern-australia

Fri Aug 2 11:10:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Justin Warren

item.title: Education Seminar Student Showcase
item.description:
Description

Eight short talks from high school students across Australia. They'll be talking about projects they've built with Python using machine learning, robotics, markov models and more!

https://2019.pycon-au.org/education-showcase

Fri Aug 2 16:00:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Eliza Lee

item.title: Extracting tabular data from PDFs with Camelot & Excalibur
item.description:
Description

Extracting tables from PDFs is hard. The Portable Document Format was not designed for tabular data. Sadly, a lot of open data is shared as PDFs and getting tables out for analysis is a pain. Camelot and Excalibur can help you extract tabular data from PDFs very easily!

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/extracting-tabular-data-from-pdfs-with-camelot-excalibur

Fri Aug 2 10:30:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Vinayak Mehta

item.title: Flying by the seat of our pants - our journey of teaching python using drones
item.description:
Description

A few years ago we found ourselves teaching students everything from Python to Arduino. It was our plan to replace all the other languages with Python as we streamlined our course. Learn why we introduced drones, what we learned not to do and what we were surprised about.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/flying-by-the-seat-of-our-pants--our-journey-of-teaching-python-using-drones

Fri Aug 2 10:30:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Kylie Mathers

item.title: Forecasting Australia's 2019 Election with PyMC3
item.description:
Description

Can we predict the result of an Australian election before it occurs? How certain of the outcome can we be? My talk will use the 2019 Australian federal election as a case study to provide an entry-level introduction to the benefits of probabilistic forecasting and PyMC3.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/forecasting-australias-2019-election-with-pymc3

Fri Aug 2 13:30:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Martin Burgess

item.title: Forklifting Django: Migrating A Complex Django App To Kubernetes
item.description:
Description

Everyone is talking about Kubernetes, but migrating existing applications is often easier said than done. This talk will cover the tale of migrating our main Django application to Kubernetes, and all the problems and solutions we ran into along the way.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/forklifting-django-migrating-a-complex-django-app-to-kubernetes

Fri Aug 2 11:50:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Noah Kantrowitz

item.title: How to get everyone to get on board with software security: practical tips and suggestions.
item.description:
Description

Security is hard. Software development is hard. Adding security objectives to development projects can seem overwhelming and is an often-overlooked aspect of cybersecurity. This talk will give you the tools, techniques and knowledge needed to get traction and bring people on board.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/how-to-get-everyone-to-get-on-board-with-software-security-practical-tips-and-suggestions

Fri Aug 2 16:40:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Tennessee Leeuwenburg

item.title: How to lose a container in 10 minutes
item.description:
Description

Moving to the cloud and deploying containers? In this talk I discuss both the mindset shift and tech challenges, with some common mistakes made in real-life deployments with some real life. We'll also be looking at my ongoing research about how easy it is to get a container or k8s cluster pwned.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/how-to-lose-a-container-in-10-minutes

Fri Aug 2 14:50:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Sarah Young

item.title: Just Add Await: Retrofitting Async Into Django
item.description:
Description

Writing async code from scratch is hard; trying to add it into a large, existing framework is harder. Learn about the problems we face trying to make Django async while maintaining backwards compatibility, as well as the problems maintaining hybrid sync-and-async Python codebases in general.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/just-add-await-retrofitting-async-into-django

Fri Aug 2 14:10:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Andrew Godwin

item.title: Learn to control your brain: Brain Computer Interfacing with Python
item.description:
Description

Neurofeedback is a brain-computer interface where a person’s own brain waves are audio/visually presented back in real-time after they’ve been recorded and filtered within a few milliseconds. We present methods to allow people to see their own brainwaves with python.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/learn-to-control-your-brain-brain-computer-interfacing-with-python

Fri Aug 2 16:40:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Johan van der Meer

item.title: Machine Learning and Cyber Security - Detecting malicious URLs in the haystack
item.description:
Description

Today, security teams are in an increasingly one-sided battle to defend against a myriad of cyber attacks. Web-based attacks are often devastating, with conventional blacklists and reputation-based defence tactics not able to identify previously unseen malicious URLs. Is AI the solution?

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/machine-learning-and-cyber-security--detecting-malicious-urls-in-the-haystack

Fri Aug 2 17:20:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Alistair

item.title: New Phone, Who Dis?: Human Authentication in the Digital Age
item.description:
Description

When proving somebody’s identity, it’s usually an important matter and critical to get right. With digital licences springing up around the globe, including here in New South Wales, how can we be sure that the computer is telling the truth? Does digitising the process actually improve it?

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/new-phone-who-dis-human-authentication-in-the-digital-age

Fri Aug 2 10:30:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Yaakov Smith

item.title: Not a long time ago, in a galaxy not very far away, an astronomer and a computer scientist walk into a bar...
item.description:
Description

Python is one of the most popular programming languages in astronomy. In this talk, I will tell a story about how Python helped me to develop a software tool for galaxy modelling, and tackle the scientific and technical challenges that arise in the Big Data era of astronomy.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/not-a-long-time-ago-in-a-galaxy-not-very-far-away-an-astronomer-and-a-computer-scientist-walk-into-a-bar

Fri Aug 2 16:00:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Georgios Bekiaris

item.title: Opening Doors with JSON Web Tokens
item.description:
Description

As the old saying goes, when one door closes, it can only be reopened when identify yourself with a valid JSON Web Token.This talk introduces JWT, secure authentication, and delegated authority, to demonstrate how to secure IoT devices without exposing them to the internet.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/opening-doors-with-json-web-tokens

Fri Aug 2 09:30:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Ben Dechrai

item.title: Pony, Cat, and Paw: Getting Started with the Open Source Menagerie
item.description:
Description

The way to your first open source pull request leads through many implicit conventions and tools you're expected to learn. Let's look at what you'll need for your first Django contribution, where to find help, and what challenges you're likely to encounter.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/pony-cat-and-paw-getting-started-with-the-open-source-menagerie

Fri Aug 2 16:00:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Tobias Kunze

item.title: Safely eval Python syntax using the AST module
item.description:
Description

Allow your users to supply queries or define rules using Python syntax and safely eval them. Processing an AST into safely executable code.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/safely-eval-python-syntax-using-the-ast-module

Fri Aug 2 10:30:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Tim Savage

item.title: Securing your AWS Identity Management pipeline with PyTest
item.description:
Description

Amazon's Identity and Access Management is a risky needle to thread when it comes to deploying into the cloud, especially when it comes to empowering your developers to make their own changes. In this talk I will be showing how to leverage PyTest to test your policies before they hit production.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/securing-your-aws-identity-management-pipeline-with-pytest

Fri Aug 2 11:50:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Sean Johnson

item.title: Stealing Chrome cookies without a password
item.description:
Description

A new technique to steal someone's Chrome cookies once you've compromised their machine. Cooler because it doesn't need root 😎. This talk is about how the technique was found, how it works, and what you can do with it.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/stealing-chrome-cookies-without-a-password

Fri Aug 2 13:30:00 2019 at C3.
item.dc:creator: "Alex"

item.title: The Unspeakable Horror of Discovering You Didn't Write Tests
item.description:
Description

I didn't write tests. I'm here to help you avoid making the same mistake.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/the-unspeakable-horror-of-discovering-you-didnt-write-tests

Fri Aug 2 16:40:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Melanie Crutchfield

item.title: Threat Modeling the Death Star
item.description:
Description

Threat modeling is one of the most important security activities. Yet they are usually done by security experts and can be quite dry and boring.This talk will cover a different way to do Threat Models by using Attack Trees. Attack trees are an easy, fun, engaging and inclusive for everyone.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/threat-modeling-the-death-star

Fri Aug 2 16:00:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Mario Areias

item.title: Understanding GPUs
item.description:
Description

With torch and tensorflow we have begun to rely on GPUs to speed up computations. Deep Learning or not, GPUs can provide massive computation speed ups but it's not a panacea as NVIDIA would have you believe. Understanding how GPUs work can tell us where we should and shouldn't use them.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/understanding-gpus

Fri Aug 2 14:50:00 2019 at Cockle Bay
item.dc:creator: Varun Nayyar

item.title: Using Dash by Plotly for Interactive Visualisation of Crime Data
item.description:
Description

Dash is a great Python framework for building data visualisation websites. In this talk I discuss the framework basics, explore a sample site and describe its use for an enterprise application to graph crime statistics. I finish with clear pros and cons of the Dash framework from our perspective.

Slides for the talk AND more resources are at http://www.halloleo.net/talks/dash_for_crime

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/using-dash-by-plotly-for-interactive-visualisation-of-crime-data

Fri Aug 2 11:10:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Leo Broska

item.title: Using Python, Django, and ruthlessness to protect people from social media harassment.
item.description:
Description

In this talk, I present 'secateur', a tool for Twitter users to protect themselves from some forms of online harassment. I discuss using Python and Django to create tools that integrate with Twitter, use its APIs, and block lots of people (LOTS of people).

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/using-python-django-and-ruthlessness-to-protect-people-from-social-media-harassment

Fri Aug 2 17:20:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Tom Eastman

item.title: Using Python, Flask and Docker To Teach Web Pentesting
item.description:
Description

Having to teach 70 or so students how to break into websites involves building infrastructure to host a lot of websites which are designed to be hacked, poked, prodded and brute forced. Hear us talk about how we were able to keep up thanks to python + friends!

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/using-python-flask-and-docker-to-teach-web-pentesting

Fri Aug 2 14:10:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Zain Afzal

item.title: Using Python to make learning Python better
item.description:
Description

As programmers one of the biggest super-powers we have is to improve the world by making new tools, automating work and making the tedious easy. As educators we know that things like personalised learning, scaffolding, and feedback really help our students. But doing all that can be challenging! We don’t have the tools, and it’s really tedious. Hang on!? Isn’t that our super-power?

In this talk I’ll explore how we can use our super-powers as programmers (and as educators) to improve our own practice. I’ll talk about how we can help develop deeper understanding in our students, and use tools (that we build) to do it! Programming isn’t just for “app developers” it’s something that everyone can use, so let’s demonstrate that by using it ourselves.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/using-python-to-make-learning-python-better

Fri Aug 2 09:15:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Ben Taylor

item.title: WASM matter?
item.description:
Description

One of the biggest developments in web technology in the last few years is the emergence of WASM - Web Assembly. But what is WASM? Can you use it in your web projects? Should you? And if so... how?

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/wasm-matter

Fri Aug 2 13:30:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Russell Keith-Magee

item.title: Web Accessibility In Django
item.description:
Description

Many developers want to build accessible applications,but don't know where to start. This talk will cover common accessibility issues and how to address them. The audience will learn about how disabled users interact with web apps, how to build more accessible sites and W3C accessibility guidelines.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/web-accessibility-in-django

Fri Aug 2 11:10:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: Parth Shandilya

item.title: What makes Micro:bits different?
item.description:
Description

There's many different ways to learn to code, and how you start your students' journey changes what challenges they'll face.This talk will highlight some of the differences when using Micro:bits, and how to overcome the challenges.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/what-makes-microbits-different

Fri Aug 2 11:50:00 2019 at C3.4 & C3.5
item.dc:creator: Jack Reichelt

item.title: You don't always need NumPy
item.description:
Description

The numerical Python ecosystem and communities are mature and powerful, but sometimes we can be too quick to reach for the numerical hammer when simpler options exist. This talk will outline some areas where the numerical stack may not be the best starting point, and survey some alternatives.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/you-dont-always-need-numpy

Fri Aug 2 09:30:00 2019 at C3.6
item.dc:creator: Sam Hames

item.title: Rust's Recipes for Code and Community
item.description:
Description

In some ways, a browser engine seems to have little in common with a web framework. But both are ambitious software projects, approached by large groups of diverse people trying and sometimes failing to cooperate, collaborate, and code together. This talk shares firsthand observations, collected over 3 years of working within the Rust and Servo teams at Mozilla as well as volunteering on the Rust Community Team, about what all developers can learn from Rust's approaches to the universal challenges of code and community.

https://2019.pycon-au.org/talks/rust-s-recipes-for-code-and-community

Fri Aug 2 09:15:00 2019 at C3.3
item.dc:creator: E. Dunham
